dc_title_s: Urban Setting Designation Areas, Groundwater: Ohio
dc_description_s: Ohio EPA’s ground water protection requirements for voluntary cleanups are designed to address risks to residents and the environment posed by contaminated ground water. Many of these properties are located in highly urbanized areas which rely on community water systems to supply residents with safe drinking water. In those areas, ground water that contains chemicals from prior industrial or commercial activities poses no perceptible risk to the community because the ground water is not being used and will not be used for drinking water purposes in the foreseeable future. In these situations, an Urban Setting Designation (USD) may be appropriate. A USD recognizes that cleaning up the ground water to drinking water standards is not necessary because no one will be drinking the ground water. Other possible exposures to contaminated ground water (such as exposures to wildlife or streams in the area, or volatilization of contaminants to indoor air) still must be addressed even when a USD is granted for an area. USDs can be granted only by the director of Ohio EPA. The request must successfully demonstrate the property (or properties) meets all the criteria of a USD as specified in Ohio Administrative Code (OAC) rule 3745-300-10 before such a designation can be granted. The use of a urban setting  designation (USD) to establish ground water response requirements for  a property undergoing a voluntary action is contingent upon the following: Verification that the boundaries of the property undergoing the voluntary action lie completely within the USD area; and verification that no significant change of circumstances has occurred that would affect the criteria upon which the USD is approved at the time of the issuance of a no further action letter for the property, in accordance with OAC 3745-300-10(C)(3) and this letter. Visit the http://epa.ohio.gov/derr/volunt/volunt.aspx#123276680-usds-and-other-director-approvals-prior-to-issuance-of-nfa-letter. Ohio EPA website for more information on Urban Setting Designations in Ohio.
